articles.title: JULY 1987
articles.summary: This document outlines the San Jose Astronomical Association's (SJAA) upcoming events for July and August 1987. Key activities include an annual membership picnic with a star party, general meetings featuring talks on astrophotography, indoor astronomy classes, board meetings, and multiple field expeditions for astronomical observation at Fremont Peak State Park and Yosemite National Park.

articles.title: FIELD OF VIEW
articles.summary: The San Jose Astronomical Association (SJAA) is hosting its annual picnic on Saturday, July 18th, at Grant Ranch County Park's Rose Garden, starting around noon. The SJAA will provide main dishes and condiments, encouraging members to bring a shared side dish. The event includes the installation of new officers and a star party in the evening, with directions to the park provided.

articles.title: YOSEMITE GLACIER POINT STAR PARTY
articles.summary: The Yosemite Glacier Point Star Party's group camp area for free camping is now fully booked due to early registrations. Individuals still wishing to attend are advised to arrive early on Friday, August 21st, to secure an individual campsite as other park guests depart.

articles.title: BIG BEAR TELESCOPE MAKERS CONFERENCE
articles.summary: This article introduces a report on the Big Bear Telescope Makers Conference, presented through two distinct viewpoints. Tom Parker offers a first-time attendee's perspective, while the editor provides insights from his tenth annual visit. The combined articles aim to give readers a comprehensive understanding of the conference.

articles.title: FISHING FOR STARLIGHT
articles.summary: The August 1st General Meeting will focus on astrophotography, showcasing how amateur astronomers now achieve observatory-quality images using a wide range of equipment, from basic cameras to advanced electronic systems. The multi-media presentation will feature live electronic video images of the night sky and a 15-minute slide and music show highlighting top amateur astrophotography.

articles.title: MEMBERSHIP RENEWALS
articles.summary: This announcement reminds current SJAA members to renew their membership to continue receiving Sky & Telescope magazine and the Ephemeris. Members should use the renewal form in the Ephemeris and send it along with their Sky & Telescope renewal notice to Jack Peterson. August is the final month the Ephemeris will be mailed to non-renewed members.

articles.title: A NEW BABY!
articles.summary: Rick and Deborah Morales welcomed their new baby girl, Carmen Christine, on June 11, 1987. The community extends its warmest congratulations to the proud parents on this joyous occasion.

articles.title: NEW COMPUTER FOR THE SJAA
articles.summary: The SJAA Board of Directors has approved and purchased a new IBM clone computer, featuring a 20MB hard disk drive, for the production of the "Ephemeris" and for various club functions like the annual auction. This acquisition will replace the previous reliance on members' personal computers, though the editor anticipates a learning curve with the new MS-DOS system.

articles.title: AUCTION SUMMARY
articles.summary: The recent Astronomical Auction was a success, drawing over 150 attendees who bid on nearly 600 items, including popular eyepieces, finderscopes, and large telescopes. The event, skillfully run by auctioneer Kevin Medlock, generated over $1500 for the club, which will fund a new computer. Special thanks were extended to the volunteers who contributed behind the scenes and provided refreshments.

articles.title: BY: DON MACHHOLZ AND RICH PAGE
articles.summary:
## BY: DON MACHHOLZ AND RICH PAGE

Joseph D. Grant (Ranch County) Park consists of 9500 acres between San Jose and Lick Observatory. Our club has observed from both the developed portion of the park a...

articles.title: COMET COMMENTS
articles.summary: Don Machholz provides an update on several comets, noting that Comet Wilson is temporarily unobservable from the Northern Hemisphere and Halley's Comet is very faint. The article details the recovery of Periodic Comet Harrington (1987h) by Gehrels and Scotti, and the discovery of Comet Shoemaker (1987o) by Carolyn and Eugene Shoemaker. Carolyn Shoemaker's discovery marks her ninth photographic comet, surpassing Caroline Herschel's record for comet discoveries by a woman.

articles.title: Comet Sorrells (1986n)
articles.summary: This article provides an ephemeris and observational guide for Comet Sorrells (1986n) from late June to early August. It details the comet's transition from the morning to evening sky, its path through the constellation Aquila and the Milky Way, and its gradual dimming as it recedes from Earth and the Sun. Distances from both celestial bodies are also noted for the end of July.

articles.title: Comet Nishikawa-Takamizawa-Tago (1987c)
articles.summary: This article provides observational data for Comet Nishikawa-Takamizawa-Tago (1987c) from late June to early August, detailing its celestial coordinates, position south of Spica, and apparent magnitude as it fades. It notes the comet is better placed for Southern Hemisphere observers in the evening sky and estimates its orbital period at 2483 years based on SAO elements. By late July, the comet was approximately 220 million miles from both the Earth and the Sun.

articles.title: Periodic Comet Grigg-Skjellerup (1986m)
articles.summary: This article provides observational data for Periodic Comet Grigg-Skjellerup (1986m) for June through August, detailing its celestial coordinates, elongation, and increasing apparent magnitude. With an orbital period of 5.10 years, it was closest to the sun on June 18th and travels through the constellations Leo and the Realm of Galaxies, described as a dim comet primarily setting around midnight.

articles.title: Periodic Comet Klemola (1987i)
articles.summary: Periodic Comet Klemola (1987i) was discovered in 1965 and has an orbital period of 10.9 years. It is currently visible in the morning sky, south of the Square of Pegasus, with estimated magnitudes ranging from 12.4 to 11.7 between late June and early August. Observing this relatively dim comet is described as a challenge for astronomers with large telescopes.

articles.title: SEEKING COMETS
articles.summary: This article details exceptions to the standard rules of comet naming, highlighting instances where comets were named based on their 'greatness', the month of their appearance, the hemisphere they were seen in, or specific events like an eclipse. It also discusses comets named after astronomers who calculated their orbits, observatories where they were discovered, or instruments and personnel involved in their detection.

articles.title: CHANGING TIMES AT RIVERSIDE
articles.summary: The author expresses disappointment with the 19th annual Riverside Telescope Maker's Conference (RTMC), noting a significant shift from its original focus on amateur telescope making and innovation towards rampant commercialism. He observes a decline in unique home-built telescope displays, an overwhelming presence of vendors, and an emphasis on sales over genuine astronomical craftsmanship and observation. Despite a large turnout and meeting Dr. Clyde Tombaugh, the author feels the conference has lost its core purpose, suggesting organizers rethink its goals.

articles.title: SALLY RIDE LEAVES NASA
articles.summary: Sally Ride, the first U.S. woman astronaut to fly in space and former head of a U.S. space goals study, is leaving NASA this autumn. She will be joining the Stanford University Center for International Security and Arms Control.

articles.title: ARIANE LAUNCHES TO RESUME IN AUGUST
articles.summary: Ariane launches are scheduled to resume in August, pending the successful completion of validation and acceptance tests for its third stage. The manifest for these upcoming launches includes Australia's Aussat K3 and ESA/Eutelsat ECA4 as payloads.

articles.title: SHUTTLE FAILURE FALLOUT
articles.summary: The U.S. Department of Defense (DOD) is experiencing a backlog of 12 unlaunched satellites due to Shuttle and Titan failures, a number expected to increase. This situation may force DOD to move payloads to expendable launch vehicles, potentially freeing up Shuttle space for commercial and scientific missions. The aerospace industry is also suffering, with a drastic drop in commercial satellite orders this year, attributed to the ongoing launch issues.

articles.title: SHUTTLE SOLID MOTOR TEST CONDUCTED
articles.summary: A full-scale Solid Rocket Booster (SRB) firing was conducted on May 27 to collect data on the old design and test minor improvements for a new design. Concurrently, advancements in the shuttle liquid rocket motor have extended turbine blade life significantly. Despite extensive testing, NASA has once again postponed the next shuttle launch date to no earlier than June 1988.

articles.title: SOVIETS TEST "ENERGIA" HEAVY LIFT BOOSTER
articles.summary: The Soviet Union successfully conducted the first flight test of its new "Energia" heavy-lift booster on May 15. This Saturn 5 class vehicle boasts 6.5 million pounds of thrust and can lift 220,000 lbs payloads, including a potential Soviet space shuttle. The article notes that the U.S. lags significantly in heavy-lift capabilities, with a new U.S. Air Force booster capable of lifting 100,000 lbs not expected until 1993.

articles.title: ATLAS LAUNCHED SUCCESSFULLY MAY 15
articles.summary: The Atlas-H rocket was successfully launched on May 15 from Vandenberg AFB. It is believed to have carried a package of Navy ocean surveillance satellites into orbit.

articles.title: ASTRO ADS
articles.summary: A Celestron 8 telescope, complete with a tripod, wedge, four eyepieces, and a star diagonal, is listed for sale at $1100. Contact information for Robert Scott in San Jose, CA, is provided for interested buyers.

articles.title: Riverside, the First Time
articles.summary: This article chronicles the author's exciting first experience at the annual Riverside Telescope Maker's Conference (RTMC) in the San Bernardino Mountains. It details the journey, the bustling atmosphere for astronomy bargains from vendors, memorable lectures including one by Dr. Clyde Tombaugh, and opportunities for observing and socializing with fellow enthusiasts. Despite minor issues, the author found the event highly valuable and plans to return, appreciating its blend of technical interest and community spirit.

articles.title: GENERAL MEETINGS
articles.summary: The SJAA holds monthly General Meetings and "Indoor Star Parties" at the Los Gatos Red Cross building, providing a welcoming environment for members interested in various astronomical pursuits. These meetings take place on the 4th Saturday of each month, starting at 8 PM, and the article includes directions to the venue.

articles.title: INDOOR STAR PARTIES
articles.summary: Indoor Star Parties are monthly Saturday evening gatherings for amateur astronomers to socialize, discuss astronomy, and share equipment like telescopes. These events, held at the Los Gatos Red Cross Building, also feature astrophotography slideshows, SJAA board meetings, and introductory astronomy workshops. Members are encouraged to bring their telescopes and accessories to share with the group.

articles.title: HENRY COE STATE PARK
articles.summary: This document provides detailed directions to Henry Coe State Park from Hwy 101 South, instructing visitors to take the East Dunne exit and continue east for about 12 miles. It describes the park entrance, the location of the locked club gate (requiring a combination), and advises arriving before dark to find an observing site. The primary setup location for SJAA equipment is just a short distance up a hill past this gate.

articles.title: FREMONT PEAK STATE PARK
articles.summary: Fremont Peak State Park is detailed as a significant astronomical observing site for the San Jose Astronomical Association (SJAA), known for hosting numerous telescopes at Coulter Camp during clear new moon weekends, and housing the FPOA's public observatory. The article provides directions to this 3000-foot elevation location, along with publication information for the SJAA's monthly bulletin "EPHEMERIS," and a directory of the club's officers and board members.

articles.title: SAN JOSE ASTRONOMICAL ASSOCIATION MEMBERSHIP APPLICATION
articles.summary: This document is a membership application form for the San Jose Astronomical Association (SJAA). It details different membership tiers, including 'Membership Only', 'Membership/S&T', and 'Junior (Under 18)', along with their corresponding fees. The form provides instructions for submission, either by mail to the treasurer or in person at an SJAA meeting.

articles.title: Questionnaire (optional)
articles.summary: This document presents an optional questionnaire designed to gather information about an individual's astronomical interests, telescope ownership, and areas of expertise where they might be able to assist others. It also includes contact and mailing information for the SJAA EPHEMERIS, a non-profit organization based in San Jose, CA.
